title: Information Trust and Disinformation

informationTrust.description: How we know what information to trust in the torrent
keyPoints: Trust is fragile but solid, happens in quirky places
East Germany paradox: low-trust surface, high-trust underground networks
Forwarding info to group = putting reputation behind it

gazaInformationWar.description: Contradictory credible sources about Gaza/Israel conflict
keyPoints: Multiple credible sources contradict each other
Israeli public has limited news access about Gaza
Can't figure out 'what's so' even with discernment

disinformationMechanics.description: How false information spreads and can be fought
keyPoints: Misattributed quotes epidemic (Marcus Aurelius quote was Tolstoy)
Elon Musk-Baltimore Ravens sponsorship story: completely false but plausible
11 ways to fight disinformation - none work really well
No business model for fighting disinformation, but strong model for spreading it
Focus should be on amplifiers/forwarders, not just sources

journalismDeath.questions: What replaces it? People always need information even in terrible situations

storiesShared.summary: DDR had 1-in-10 informants (low surface trust), but underground networks had incredibly high trust because lives were on the line. People will never experience trust that deep again.
storiesShared.impact: Reframes how we think about trust - it emerges strongest under pressure

storiesShared.summary: Perfect quote: 'Far better to be rejected by society than subsumed by a mob of idiots.' Turned out Leo Tolstoy made it up and attributed it to Marcus Aurelius.
storiesShared.impact: Example of quote attribution problem - happens constantly

storiesShared.summary: $500M sponsorship offer story spread widely in last 24 hours - completely made up but plausible
storiesShared.impact: Shows how false but plausible stories spread rapidly

storiesShared.summary: Learned not to pour protein drink on laptop, now working from iPad which is 'not too bad'
storiesShared.impact: Light moment - 'iPad: not too bad' as tagline

frameworks.name: 11 Ways to Fight Disinformation
frameworks.problem: None work really well, most lack business model

frameworks.name: Brain Defense
frameworks.description: Better framing than 'media literacy' - about defending against hateful, ignorant, deceitful memes and bumper stickers

frameworks.name: Electronic Graffiti
frameworks.context: Singapore company 20 years ago - failed business model
frameworks.description: App allowing annotations/corrections on any website visible to other app users
frameworks.problem: Never got business model, never worked

questionsRaised: How do we know which information to trust and forward?
How do trusted communities avoid being spun and losing track?
What replaces journalism as it dies?
How do we handle contradictory credible sources?
Why is there a business model for spreading disinformation but not for fighting it?
How do we build 'brain defense' at scale?
What's the degree of information lockdown in Gaza?
Can we create something like electronic graffiti that works?
